questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic stable angina is seen in the outpatient department. She is already taking aspirin and statins, but continues to experience occasional chest pain during exertion. Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice for prophylactic treatment of her angina? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oral nitroglycerine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral nitroglycerine, a long-acting nitrate preparation, is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina to prevent angina episodes during exertion.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).
  • • Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.
  • • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.
  • • Option A. Plane synovial:
  • • Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.
  • • Option B.
  • • Primary cartilaginous:
  • • Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.
  • • Option C. Secondary cartilaginous:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:
  • ➤ Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:
  • ➤ Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint Middle radioulnar joint Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Middle radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.
  • ➤ The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:
  • ➤ The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.
  • ➤ The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  • ➤ Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • ➤ Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Defect of enzyme tyrosine transaminase (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 2 tyrosinemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by the body's inability to effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine. There are three types of tyrosinemia, each associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type I tyrosinemia : This type is associated with a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option A. Type I tyrosinemia
  • • Option C. Alkaptonuria : This condition involves a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option C. Alkaptonuria
  • • Option D. Type III tyrosinemia : This type involves a deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option D. Type III tyrosinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 2 tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme t yrosine t ransaminase and is also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome or Oculocutaneous syndrome.

  • ➤ t
  • ➤ t

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine
  • ➤ S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor . It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.
  • ➤ S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise. While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.
  • ➤ The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise.
  • ➤ The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise.
  • ➤ While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.
  • ➤ While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of diabetes is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metformin is commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea as a side effect, making it important for healthcare providers to monitor patients for this gastrointestinal disturbance when prescribing the medication.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.correct_answer: D. Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT. The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible. FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.
  • ➤ Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  • ➤ The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  • ➤ FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.

questions.text: A 2-month pregnant female presented with Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Quinine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Quinine is often used as a treatment for malaria during pregnancy, especially if other options are not available or suitable. However, it is usually more associated with the treatment of Plasmodium falciparum rather than Plasmodium vivax.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of a child with cleft lip and palate with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Patau syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) presents with multiple congenital anomalies, including cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and umbilical hernia, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

questions.text: Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is most likely depicted in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Subdural hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The crescent-shaped collection of blood on a CT scan that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural reflections is indicative of a subdural hematoma, a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer.

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon .
  • ➤ cocaine bugs
  • ➤ magnun phenomenon

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conjunctival xerosis is specifically associated with Vitamin A deficiency and is a significant indicator of this deficiency, affecting the epithelial tissues of the eye.

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: During which phase of cardiac cycle is the first heart sound produced? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phases of cardiac cycle -
  • ➤ Phases of cardiac cycle -
  • ➤ Cardiac cycle in ventricles last for 0.8 sec Ventricular Systole - 0.3 sec. – consist of 3 phases. Ventricular Diastole - 0,5 sec - consist of 5 phases.
  • ➤ Cardiac cycle in ventricles last for 0.8 sec
  • ➤ Ventricular Systole - 0.3 sec. – consist of 3 phases.
  • ➤ Ventricular Diastole - 0,5 sec - consist of 5 phases.
  • ➤ Phases of ventricular Systole -
  • ➤ Phases of ventricular Systole -
  • ➤ 1 st Phase - Starts with closure of Mitral valve, which produces S1 sound. This phase is called as Isovolumetric contraction, it ends by opening of aortic valve.
  • ➤ 1 st Phase -
  • ➤ 2 nd Phase - Phase of Rapid ejection - 2/3rd of the stroke volume is ejected.
  • ➤ 2 nd Phase
  • ➤ 3 rd Phase - Phase of Slow ejection phase: Approximately 1/3rd of the remaining stroke volume is ejected
  • ➤ 3 rd Phase
  • ➤ Phases of ventricular Diastole -
  • ➤ Phases of ventricular Diastole -
  • ➤ 1 st phase (Protodiastole) – which occurs just before the beginning of diastole (last for 0.04 Sec.)
  • ➤ 1 st phase (Protodiastole)
  • ➤ 2 nd Phase - starts with closure of aortic valve, which produces S2 sound which is taken as- beginning of diastole proper. This phase is known as Isovolumetric relaxation.
  • ➤ 2 nd Phase
  • ➤ Volume - constant, pressure – decrease
  • ➤ 3 rd Phase - Early Rapid filling phase and 4 th Slow filling phase (passive filling of 2/3 rd of blood)
  • ➤ 3 rd Phase
  • ➤ * S3 sound produce due to rapid filling phase. Normally Can not be heard except few Hyperdynamic condition like: exercise, Pregnancy
  • ➤ 4. Active filling phase (Remaining 1/3 rd of filling due to atrial contraction)

Ans. A) 2 years

questions.text: Broca's area is situated in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inferior frontal gyrus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • ➤ Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus. Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.
  • ➤ Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • ➤ Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO 2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO 2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H 2 O. What is the diagnosis? CO 2 embolism Severe bronchospasm Pneumothorax Single bronchus intubation EtCO 2 -End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. CO2 embolism : During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.
  • • 1. CO2 embolism
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 2. Severe bronchospasm : Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.
  • • 2. Severe bronchospasm
  • • 3. Pneumothorax : A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.
  • • 3. Pneumothorax
  • • 4. Single bronchus intubation : If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.
  • • 4. Single bronchus intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1879
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy, during the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arch of aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perforation at 25 cm from the incisors during endoscopy is most likely to involve the arch of the aorta due to its anatomical position relative to the esophagus.

  • ➤ Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  • ➤ Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with fever and neurological complications. He was having respiratory difficulty during the examination. Identify the disease transmitted through the life cycle shown in the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nipah virus disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with Pteropus bats, contaminated food, or animals that have been exposed to the virus. It causes severe respiratory and neurological symptoms with a high fatality rate and no available vaccine.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia after consuming an unknown substance. There was presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following substances was most likely consumed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning should be suspected in patients presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and symptoms resembling alcohol intoxication. The formation of oxalate crystals and the subsequent hypocalcemia are key features that differentiate it from other toxic ingestions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe

options.label: D
options.text: Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy. It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block. Management includes Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended. Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy. Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy. Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.
  • • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • • Management includes
  • • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy : Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.
  • • Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
  • • Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction : Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.
  • • Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
  • • Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe : Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.
  • • Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).
  • • Methotrexate with folinic acid:
  • • < 6: LOW RISK > 7 HIGH RISK
  • • < 6: LOW RISK
  • • > 7 HIGH RISK
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.
  • • Option B. Methotrexate:
  • • Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.
  • • Option C. EMACO regimen:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid
  • ➤ Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition

questions.text: The anterior incisors of a child with white patches turned brown following over supplementation of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fluorine in water

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description of white patches turning brown on the anterior incisors of a child is indicative of dental fluorosis. This condition occurs due to excessive fluoride intake, particularly during the years when teeth are developing. Fluoride is beneficial in small amounts for dental health, but excessive exposure, often due to high levels in drinking water or overuse of fluoride supplements, can lead to fluorosis, which manifests as mottling and discoloration of teeth.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chlorine in Water: While chlorine is used to purify water, it does not cause dental fluorosis, which is characterized by changes in the color and structure of teeth. Chlorine at levels used in water treatment does not typically result in dental discoloration.
  • • Option A. Chlorine in Water:
  • • Option C. Vitamin A: While excessive Vitamin A intake can lead to toxicity with a variety of symptoms, it does not cause dental fluorosis. Vitamin A toxicity typically presents with symptoms such as skin changes, vision disturbances, and bone pain, but not with changes in tooth color.
  • • Option C. Vitamin A:
  • • Option D. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is not associated with dental discoloration. Deficiency of riboflavin can lead to mouth and lip sores, but its excess does not result in changes similar to fluorosis.
  • • Option D. Riboflavin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid. The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water. Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight. Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth. A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.
  • ➤ Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid.
  • ➤ The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water.
  • ➤ Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight.
  • ➤ Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth.
  • ➤ A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? ( INICET Nov 2020) A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A, B & C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin. A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis. Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • ➤ The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • ➤ A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • ➤ Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • ➤ Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.
  • ➤ Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.
